scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: All
line: Speak, speak.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: All
line: Resolved. resolved.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: All
line: We know't, we know't.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Is't a verdict?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: All
line: No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: One word, good citizens.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: What authority surfeits on would relieve us: if they

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: would yield us but the superfluity, while it were

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: but they think we are too dear: the leanness that

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: inventory to particularise their abundance; our

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: our pikes, ere we become rakes: for the gods know I

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: All
line: Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Consider you what services he has done for his country?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Very well; and could be content to give him good

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: report fort, but that he pays himself with being proud.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: it to that end: though soft-conscienced men can be

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: content to say it was for his country he did it to

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: please his mother and to be partly proud; which he

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: is, even till the altitude of his virtue.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: What he cannot help in his nature, you account a

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: What shouts are these? The other side o' the city

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: is risen: why stay we prating here? to the Capitol!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: All
line: Come, come.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Soft! who comes here?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: the people.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go you

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: With bats and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: which now we'll show 'em in deeds. They say poor

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: suitors have strong breaths: they shall know we

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: have strong arms too.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Will you undo yourselves?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: I tell you, friends, most charitable care

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Have the patricians of you. For your wants,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Against the Roman state, whose course will on

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Of more strong link asunder than can ever

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: The gods, not the patricians, make it, and

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: You are transported by calamity

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Thither where more attends you, and you slander

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: The helms o' the state, who care for you like fathers,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: When you curse them as enemies.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Care for us! True, indeed! They ne'er cared for us

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: yet: suffer us to famish, and their store-houses

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: crammed with grain; make edicts for usury, to

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: established against the rich, and provide more

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: there's all the love they bear us.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Either you must

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: To stale 't a little more.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Well, I'll hear it, sir: yet you must not think to

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: you, deliver.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: There was a time when all the body's members

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: That only like a gulf it did remain

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: I' the midst o' the body, idle and unactive,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Like labour with the rest, where the other instruments

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: And, mutually participate, did minister

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Unto the appetite and affection common

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Of the whole body. The belly answer'd--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Well, sir, what answer made the belly?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: For, look you, I may make the belly smile

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: As well as speak--it tauntingly replied

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: To the discontented members, the mutinous parts

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: That envied his receipt; even so most fitly

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: As you malign our senators for that

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: They are not such as you.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Your belly's answer? What!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: The kingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: With other muniments and petty helps

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: In this our fabric, if that they--

speaker: MENENIUS
line: What then?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: 'Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? what then?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Who is the sink o' the body,--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Well, what then?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: The former agents, if they did complain,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: What could the belly answer?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: I will tell you

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: If you'll bestow a small--of what you have little--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Ye're long about it.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Note me this, good friend;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Your most grave belly was deliberate,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Not rash like his accusers, and thus answer'd:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: 'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: 'That I receive the general food at first,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Which you do live upon; and fit it is,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Because I am the store-house and the shop

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Of the whole body: but, if you do remember,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: I send it through the rivers of your blood,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: And, through the cranks and offices of man,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.

line: Whereby they live: and though that all at once,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: You, my good friends,'--this says the belly, mark me,--

speaker: First Citizen

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: And leave me but the bran.' What say you to't?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Citizen
line: It was an answer: how apply you this?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: The senators of Rome are this good belly,

speaker: MENENIUS
line: And you the mutinous members; for examine

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.

line: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Of their own choice: one's Junius Brutus,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Sicinius Velutus, and I know not--'Sdeath!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: The rabble should have first unroof'd the city,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Ere so prevail'd with me: it will in time

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Win upon power and throw forth greater themes

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: For insurrection's arguing.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: This is strange.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Go, get you home, you fragments!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Messenger
line: Where's Caius Marcius?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Here: what's the matter?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: Messenger
line: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: I am glad on 't: then we shall ha' means to vent

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Senator
line: Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Senator
line: The Volsces are in arms.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: They have a leader,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to 't.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: I sin in envying his nobility,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: And were I any thing but what I am,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: I would wish me only he.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: You have fought together.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Were half to half the world by the ears and he.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Upon my party, I'ld revolt to make

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Only my wars with him: he is a lion

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: That I am proud to hunt.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Senator
line: Then, worthy Marcius,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Senator
line: Attend upon Cominius to these wars.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: It is your former promise.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Sir, it is;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: What, art thou stiff? stand'st out?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: TITUS
line: No, Caius Marcius;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: TITUS
line: I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: TITUS
line: Ere stay behind this business.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: O, true-bred!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Senator
line: Your company to the Capitol; where, I know,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Senator
line: Our greatest friends attend us.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: TITUS
line: To COMINIUS                Lead you on.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: TITUS
line: To MARCIUS  Follow Cominius; we must follow you;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: TITUS
line: Right worthy you priority.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Noble Marcius!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: First Senator
line: To the Citizens  Hence to your homes; be gone!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Nay, let them follow:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Your valour puts well forth: pray, follow.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: He has no equal.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: When we were chosen tribunes for the people,--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Mark'd you his lip and eyes?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Nay. but his taunts.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Be-mock the modest moon.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: The present wars devour him: he is grown

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Too proud to be so valiant.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Such a nature,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: His insolence can brook to be commanded

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Under Cominius.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Fame, at the which he aims,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: In whom already he's well graced, can not

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Better be held nor more attain'd than by

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: A place below the first: for what miscarries

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Shall be the general's fault, though he perform

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: To the utmost of a man, and giddy censure

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Will then cry out of Marcius 'O if he

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Had borne the business!'

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Besides, if things go well,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Of his demerits rob Cominius.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Come:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: In aught he merit not.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Let's hence, and hear

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: More than his singularity, he goes

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Upon this present action.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. A street.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Lets along.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: First Senator
line: So, your opinion is, Aufidius,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: First Senator
line: That they of Rome are entered in our counsels

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: First Senator
line: And know how we proceed.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Is it not yours?

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: What ever have been thought on in this state,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Since I heard thence; these are the words: I think

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: I have the letter here; yes, here it is.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: 'They have press'd a power, but it is not known

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Whether for east or west: the dearth is great;

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: The people mutinous; and it is rumour'd,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Cominius, Marcius your old enemy,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Who is of Rome worse hated than of you,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: These three lead on this preparation

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Whither 'tis bent: most likely 'tis for you:

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Consider of it.'

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: First Senator
line: Our army's in the field

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: First Senator
line: We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: First Senator
line: To answer us.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Nor did you think it folly

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: To keep your great pretences veil'd till when

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: They needs must show themselves; which

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: in the hatching,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: It seem'd, appear'd to Rome. By the discovery.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: We shall be shorten'd in our aim, which was

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: To take in many towns ere almost Rome

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Should know we were afoot.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: Second Senator
line: Noble Aufidius,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: Second Senator
line: Take your commission; hie you to your bands:

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: Second Senator
line: Let us alone to guard Corioli:

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: Second Senator
line: If they set down before 's, for the remove

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: Second Senator
line: Bring your army; but, I think, you'll find

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: Second Senator
line: They've not prepared for us.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: O, doubt not that;

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: I speak from certainties. Nay, more,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Some parcels of their power are forth already,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: And only hitherward. I leave your honours.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet,

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: 'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Till one can do no more.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: All
line: The gods assist you!

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: And keep your honours safe!

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: First Senator
line: Farewell.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: Second Senator
line: Farewell.

scene: SCENE II.  Corioli. The Senate-house.
speaker: All
line: Farewell.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself in a

line: won honour than in the embracements of his bed where

line: he would show most love. When yet he was but

speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, when

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way, when

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: for a day of kings' entreaties a mother should not

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: sell him an hour from her beholding, I, considering

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: how honour would become such a person. that it was

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: no better than picture-like to hang by the wall, if

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: danger where he was like to find fame. To a cruel

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: man.

line: But had he died in the business, madam; how then?

line: Then his good report should have been my son; I

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: therein would have found issue. Hear me profess

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love

line: alike and none less dear than thine and my good

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.

line: Indeed, you shall not.

line: Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum,

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him:

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:

line: 'Come on, you cowards! you were got in fear,

line: Though you were born in Rome:' his bloody brow

line: With his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes,

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: Like to a harvest-man that's task'd to mow

speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: Or all or lose his hire.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: His bloody brow! O Jupiter, no blood!

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: Away, you fool! it more becomes a man

line: Than gilt his trophy: the breasts of Hecuba,

line: We are fit to bid her welcome.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

line: And tread upon his neck.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: Sweet madam.

line: A crack, madam.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: She shall, she shall.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: Indeed, no, by your patience; I'll not over the

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: threshold till my lord return from the wars.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably: come,

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: you must go visit the good lady that lies in.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: my prayers; but I cannot go thither.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: Why, I pray you?

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: You would be another Penelope: yet, they say, all

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: Ithaca full of moths. Come; I would your cambric

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: were sensible as your finger, that you might leave

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: excellent news of your husband.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: O, good madam, there can be none yet.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: him last night.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: Indeed, madam?

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: whom Cominius the general is gone, with one part of

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: our Roman power: your lord and Titus Lartius are set

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: down before their city Corioli; they nothing doubt

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true,

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: thing hereafter.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: Let her alone, lady: as she is now, she will but

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VOLUMNIA
line: disease our better mirth.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: In troth, I think she would. Fare you well, then.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: Come, good sweet lady. Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: solemness out o' door. and go along with us.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: No, at a word, madam; indeed, I must not. I wish

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VIRGILIA
line: you much mirth.

scene: SCENE III.  Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
speaker: VALERIA
line: Well, then, farewell.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: My horse to yours, no.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: 'Tis done.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Agreed.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Say, has our general met the enemy?

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: Messenger
line: They lie in view; but have not spoke as yet.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: So, the good horse is mine.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: I'll buy him of you.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: No, I'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him I will

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: For half a hundred years. Summon the town.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: How far off lie these armies?

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: Messenger
line: Within this mile and half.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: That we with smoking swords may march from hence,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Tutus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: No, nor a man that fears you less than he,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: That's lesser than a little.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: Hark! our drums

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: Rather than they shall pound us up: our gates,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: Which yet seem shut, we, have but pinn'd with rushes;

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: They'll open of themselves.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: Hark you. far off!

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: There is Aufidius; list, what work he makes

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Senator
line: Amongst your cloven army.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: O, they are at it!

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho!

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: They fear us not, but issue forth their city.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: With hearts more proof than shields. Advance,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: brave Titus:

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows:

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: And he shall feel mine edge.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: All the contagion of the south light on you,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: You shames of Rome! you herd of--Boils and plagues

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'd

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Further than seen and one infect another

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: That bear the shapes of men, how have you run

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: All hurt behind; backs red, and faces pale

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: And make my wars on you: look to't: come on;

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: If you'll stand fast, we'll beat them to their wives,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: As they us to our trenches followed.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: So, now the gates are ope: now prove good seconds:

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: 'Tis for the followers fortune widens them,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Not for the fliers: mark me, and do the like.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Soldier
line: Fool-hardiness; not I.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: Second Soldier
line: Nor I.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Soldier
line: See, they have shut him in.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: All
line: To the pot, I warrant him.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: What is become of Marcius?

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: All
line: Slain, sir, doubtless.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Soldier
line: Following the fliers at the very heels,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Soldier
line: With them he enters; who, upon the sudden,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Soldier
line: Clapp'd to their gates: he is himself alone,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Soldier
line: To answer all the city.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: O noble fellow!

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: And, when it bows, stands up. Thou art left, Marcius:

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Only in strokes; but, with thy grim looks and

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds,

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Thou madst thine enemies shake, as if the world

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Were feverous and did tremble.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: First Soldier
line: Look, sir.

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: O,'tis Marcius!

scene: SCENE IV.  Before Corioli.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Let's fetch him off, or make remain alike.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: First Roman
line: This will I carry to Rome.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: Second Roman
line: And I this.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: Third Roman
line: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: See here these movers that do prize their hours

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: At a crack'd drachm! Cushions, leaden spoons,

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves,

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: And hark, what noise the general makes! To him!

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius,

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Convenient numbers to make good the city;

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: To help Cominius.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st;

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Thy exercise hath been too violent for

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: A second course of fight.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Sir, praise me not;

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well:

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: The blood I drop is rather physical

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: I will appear, and fight.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Now the fair goddess, Fortune,

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman,

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Prosperity be thy page!

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Thy friend no less

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Than those she placeth highest! So, farewell.

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Thou worthiest Marcius!

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Go, sound thy trumpet in the market-place;

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Call thither all the officers o' the town,

scene: SCENE V.  Corioli. A street.
speaker: LARTIUS
line: Where they shall know our mind: away!

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Breathe you, my friends: well fought;

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: we are come off

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: We shall be charged again. Whiles we have struck,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: By interims and conveying gusts we have heard

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: The charges of our friends. Ye Roman gods!

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Lead their successes as we wish our own,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: That both our powers, with smiling

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: fronts encountering,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: May give you thankful sacrifice.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Thy news?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: The citizens of Corioli have issued,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle:

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: I saw our party to their trenches driven,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: And then I came away.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Though thou speak'st truth,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Methinks thou speak'st not well.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: How long is't since?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: Above an hour, my lord.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums:

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: And bring thy news so late?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: Spies of the Volsces

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: Held me in chase, that I was forced to wheel

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: Three or four miles about, else had I, sir,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: Messenger
line: Half an hour since brought my report.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Who's yonder,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: That does appear as he were flay'd? O gods

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Before-time seen him thus.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Within                 Come I too late?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: From every meaner man.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Come I too late?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: But mantled in your own.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: O, let me clip ye

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: As merry as when our nuptial day was done,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: And tapers burn'd to bedward!

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Flower of warriors,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: How is it with Titus Lartius?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: As with a man busied about decrees:

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Condemning some to death, and some to exile;

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other;

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Holding Corioli in the name of Rome,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: To let him slip at will.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Where is that slave

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Where is he? call him hither.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Let him alone;

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: The common file--a plague! tribunes for them!--

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: From rascals worse than they.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: But how prevail'd you?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Will the time serve to tell? I do not think.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: Where is the enemy? are you lords o' the field?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: If not, why cease you till you are so?

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Marcius,

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: We have at disadvantage fought and did

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Retire to win our purpose.

scene: SCENE VI.  Near the camp of Cominius.
speaker: MARCIUS
line: How lies their battle? know you on which side

line: To ease his breast with panting.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Worthy man!

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: First Senator
line: He cannot but with measure fit the honours

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: First Senator
line: Which we devise him.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Our spoils he kick'd at,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: And look'd upon things precious as they were

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: The common muck of the world: he covets less

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: Than misery itself would give; rewards

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: His deeds with doing them, and is content

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: COMINIUS
line: To spend the time to end it.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: He's right noble:

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Let him be call'd for.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: First Senator
line: Call Coriolanus.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: Officer
line: He doth appear.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: To make thee consul.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: I do owe them still

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: My life and services.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: It then remains

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: That you do speak to the people.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: I do beseech you,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: That I may pass this doing.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Sir, the people

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Must have their voices; neither will they bate

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: One jot of ceremony.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Put them not to't:

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Pray you, go fit you to the custom and

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Take to you, as your predecessors have,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Your honour with your form.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: It is apart

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: That I shall blush in acting, and might well

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Be taken from the people.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Mark you that?

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus;

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Show them the unaching scars which I should hide,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: As if I had received them for the hire

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Of their breath only!

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Do not stand upon't.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Wish we all joy and honour.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: Senators
line: To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: You see how he intends to use the people.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: May they perceive's intent! He will require them,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: As if he did contemn what he requested

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Should be in them to give.

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Come, we'll inform them

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace,

scene: SCENE  II.  The same. The Capitol.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I know, they do attend us.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: First Citizen
line: Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: We may, sir, if we will.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: power that we have no power to do; for if he show us

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: tongues into those wounds and speak for them; so, if

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: our noble acceptance of them. Ingratitude is

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: were to make a monster of the multitude: of the

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: which we being members, should bring ourselves to be

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: monstrous members.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: First Citizen
line: And to make us no better thought of, a little help

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: First Citizen
line: will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: First Citizen
line: himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: We have been called so of many; not that our heads

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: are some brown, some black, some auburn, some bald,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: but that our wits are so diversely coloured: and

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: and their consent of one direct way should be at

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: once to all the points o' the compass.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: fly?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: will;'tis strongly wedged up in a block-head, but

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Why that way?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: for conscience sake, to help to get thee a wife.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: You are never without your tricks: you may, you may.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: Are you all resolved to give your voices? But

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: that's no matter, the greater part carries it. I

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: say, if he would incline to the people, there was

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: never a worthier man.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: Here he comes, and in the gown of humility: mark his

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: behavior. We are not to stay all together, but to

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: by threes. He's to make his requests by

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: particulars; wherein every one of us has a single

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: honour, in giving him our own voices with our own

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: tongues: therefore follow me, and I direct you how

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: you shall go by him.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: All
line: Content, content.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: O sir, you are not right: have you not known

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: The worthiest men have done't?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: What must I say?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: 'I Pray, sir'--Plague upon't! I cannot bring

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: My tongue to such a pace:--'Look, sir, my wounds!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: I got them in my country's service, when

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: From the noise of our own drums.'

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: O me, the gods!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: You must not speak of that: you must desire them

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: To think upon you.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Think upon me! hang 'em!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: I would they would forget me, like the virtues

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Which our divines lose by 'em.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: You'll mar all:

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: I'll leave you: pray you, speak to 'em, I pray you,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: In wholesome manner.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Bid them wash their faces

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: And keep their teeth clean.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: So, here comes a brace.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: You know the cause, air, of my standing here.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Mine own desert.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Your own desert!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Ay, but not mine own desire.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: How not your own desire?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: No, sir,'twas never my desire yet to trouble the

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: poor with begging.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: gain by you.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Well then, I pray, your price o' the consulship?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: First Citizen
line: The price is to ask it kindly.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Kindly! Sir, I pray, let me ha't: I have wounds to

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: show you, which shall be yours in private. Your

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: good voice, sir; what say you?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: You shall ha' it, worthy sir.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: begged. I have your alms: adieu.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: But this is something odd.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: An 'twere to give again,--but 'tis no matter.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: voices that I may be consul, I have here the

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: customary gown.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fourth Citizen
line: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fourth Citizen
line: have not deserved nobly.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Your enigma?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fourth Citizen
line: You have been a scourge to her enemies, you have

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fourth Citizen
line: been a rod to her friends; you have not indeed loved

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fourth Citizen
line: the common people.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: You should account me the more virtuous that I have

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: estimation of them; 'tis a condition they account

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: gentle: and since the wisdom of their choice is

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: the insinuating nod and be off to them most

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: counterfeitly; that is, sir, I will counterfeit the

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: bewitchment of some popular man and give it

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech you,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: I may be consul.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fifth Citizen
line: We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fifth Citizen
line: you our voices heartily.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Fourth Citizen
line: You have received many wounds for your country.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no further.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Both Citizens
line: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Most sweet voices!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Better it is to die, better to starve,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't:

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: What custom wills, in all things should we do't,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: The dust on antique time would lie unswept,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: And mountainous error be too highly heapt

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: For truth to o'er-peer. Rather than fool it so,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Let the high office and the honour go

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: To one that would do thus. I am half through;

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: The one part suffer'd, the other will I do.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Here come more voices.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Your voices: for your voices I have fought;

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Watch'd for your voices; for Your voices bear

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: I have seen and heard of; for your voices have

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Done many things, some less, some more your voices:

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Indeed I would be consul.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Sixth Citizen
line: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Sixth Citizen
line: man's voice.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Seventh Citizen
line: Therefore let him be consul: the gods give him joy,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Seventh Citizen
line: and make him good friend to the people!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: All Citizens
line: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Worthy voices!

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: You have stood your limitation; and the tribunes

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Endue you with the people's voice: remains

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: That, in the official marks invested, you

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: Anon do meet the senate.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Is this done?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: The custom of request you have discharged:

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: The people do admit you, and are summon'd

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: To meet anon, upon your approbation.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Where? at the senate-house?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: There, Coriolanus.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: May I change these garments?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: You may, sir.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: CORIOLANUS
line: Repair to the senate-house.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: MENENIUS
line: I'll keep you company. Will you along?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: We stay here for the people.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: Fare you well.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: He has it now, and by his looks methink

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: 'Tis warm at 's heart.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: will you dismiss the people?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: SICINIUS
line: How now, my masters! have you chose this man?

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: First Citizen
line: He has our voices, sir.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: Amen, sir: to my poor unworthy notice,

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Second Citizen
line: He mock'd us when he begg'd our voices.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: Certainly

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: Third Citizen
line: He flouted us downright.

scene: SCENE III.  The same. The Forum.
speaker: First Citizen

line: Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.

line: You bless me, gods!

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

line: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: The leading of thine own revenges, take

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: The one half of my commission; and set down--

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Thy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways;

line: Whether to knock against the gates of Rome,

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: To fright them, ere destroy. But come in:

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Let me commend thee first to those that shall

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes!

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: And more a friend than e'er an enemy;

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: AUFIDIUS
line: Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand: most welcome!

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: Here's a strange alteration!

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

line: By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with

line: a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a

speaker: Second Servingman

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

line: but I thought there was more in him than I could think.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

line: So did I, I'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: man i' the world.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: I think he is: but a greater soldier than he you wot on.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: Who, my master?

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: Worth six on him.

speaker: First Servingman

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: greater soldier.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that:

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: for the defence of a town, our general is excellent.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: Ay, and for an assault too.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: O slaves, I can tell you news,-- news, you rascals!

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: What, what, what? let's partake.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: lieve be a condemned man.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: Wherefore? wherefore?

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general,

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: Caius Marcius.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: Why do you say 'thwack our general '?

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: good enough for him.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: Come, we are fellows and friends: he was ever too

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

line: He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

line: on't: before Corioli he scotched him and notched

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

line: him like a carbon ado.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Second Servingman
line: broiled and eaten him too.

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: First Servingman
line: But, more of thy news?

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: Why, he is so made on here within, as if he were son

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
speaker: Third Servingman
line: and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no

scene: SCENE V.  The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.
